column5: Quote: Originally Posted by AspencreekThe answer to your question is simply.....yes and yes! But it really doesn't matter anyway, you bring it home and put it in the fridge, then some weeks or even month's later you discover it, sitting behind that jar of pickles, take it out and spread it on your toast, and all those feelings, of solitude, the sounds and smells, and your memories wrap you like a warm blanket.Got to go check the fridge, I know I brought some back with me............OK, you folks have persuaded me! Next time I'm north of the border I'll make a point of looking for it. Thanks!Gerry

I used to bring Malkins Jam home for the entire family. My nieces would tell me how many cans of which flavors they wanted.Mom and my brother did too. Everybody loved the stuff. Now I buy it at Runnings.

Is it just me or did the flavor and consistency of Malkins change years ago and not for the better? We used to buy and enjoy it but have been very disappointed in it for the last number of years and no longer buy it. wmd

[QUOTE=andreindy;6427450]Dug in the back of fridge and found this jam I brought back for my wife a year or two ago. Lots of things are triggering thoughts of Ontario lately.[/QU Some years ago I bought two cans of blueberry jam in Canada. At the airport in Minneapolis , TSA confiscated the jam declaring the cans were weapons. Flew off to Virginia, no jam.
It will never be found in our fridge a year later because it doesn't last very long around here!! Later, Jay

BINGO, yes since Malkins sold out or the name changed, whatever happened, I agree not nearly as good. I no longer buy it either. Used to stock up on our trips. Haven't bought it for years. Just not the same....
Maybe it has changed, maybe not, I don't care, it's the 1 of a couple more items I bring back. Besides, does it really matter anyway. Not to me.
I'm in this camp. Really good (as opposed to really, really good) is good enough for me.
Dug in the back of fridge and found this jam I brought back for my wife a year or two ago. Lots of things are triggering thoughts of Ontario lately.
When I was a kid (many years ago) getting a can of Jam from Canada was a bigger treat then going to McDonalds.
Still is. You can buy it in MN, but it's not legit if it doesn't have a French label as well....
I buy my wife and kids some jam every year. My Mom and mother in law get one also.
Is there something especially good about jam from Canada, or is it a nostalgia thing?Gerry
Malkins Jam and Macintosh Toffee. 2 treats that i always remember from Canada and still always get!!!
We just finished out last can from last year. Good thing we are headed up shortly. Also, our adult kids get several cans for Christmas each year. They look forward to it. Tx. Jig Tyr

Both. Malkins was the brand in the old days, now called Canada's. I had my first on my first trip to Canada over 30 years ago. The stuff is so thick you have to cut it out of the can, and the flavor is so intense....

The answer to your question is simply.....yes and yes! But it really doesn't matter anyway, you bring it home and put it in the fridge, then some weeks or even month's later you discover it, sitting behind that jar of pickles, take it out and spread it on your toast, and all those feelings, of solitude, the sounds and smells, and your memories wrap you like a warm blanket. Got to go check the fridge, I know I brought some back with me............
